newsitem.title: POLAND: BPH shareholders approve $100 mln Eurobond.
newsitem.headline: BPH shareholders approve $100 mln Eurobond.

text.p: Shareholders of Poland's Bank Przemyslowo-Handlowy SA (BPH) approved on Tuesday the management's plan to issue up to $100 million of convertible bonds to expand the bank's lending, BPH said in a statement.

It said its extraordinary shareholders meeting voted in favour of management's proposal to issue up to 100,000 fixed rate bonds with a par value of $1000 each with maturity of up to five years and exchangeable for up to 1,994,000 shares.
The shareholders also approved the plan to issue the shares ex-rights and seek their bourse listing. @
The BPH shareholders authorised the management board to set the due date of the bonds the conversion rate at a later date.
Henryka Pieronkiewicz told reporters after the meeting that the proceeds from the issue would be mainly used to finance the bank's credit expansion, especially the growth of foreign currency credits.

She also denied media speculation that BPH would use the funds raised from the issue to finance a planned purchase of a stake in Powszechny Bank Kredytowy (PBK) due for sale early in the second quarter of 1997. @

"The funds raised from the bond issue will certainly not be used for a possible purchase of shares in privatised PBK. The bank (BPH) has enough money to buy a PBK stake it is interested in," Pieronkiewicz told reporters.
She said BPH had yet to decide whether the bonds would be issued through a public offering or in a private placement.
Pieronkiewicz, asked whether BPH planned to form a financial group with Kredyt Bank, PBK, Warta insurance firm and PBR bank said: @

"I will not confirm or deny reports of a planned group of five Polish financial institutions. All I can say is that BPH is interested in taking part in the consolidation of the Polish financial market," she said.
